page.title: 16Inchnadamph Nature Reserve
page.content: The reserve occupies{1,300 hectares {(3,200acres) between Loch Assynt and {Ben More Assynt}and lies south east of Inchnadamph.{Mr E.H.Vestey}(owner of Assynt Estates) agreed with the Nature Conservancy that they would start a Nature Reserve, in 1956. There are interesting{limestone}formations in- the{Stronchrubie cliffs (100m high). The valleys of the{Traligill River forming the Northern boundaries of the reserve are especially rich in{caves and underground streamways.The caves and holes were formed by acidic water dissolving the limestone and the deep crevices and corries by{glaciers sweeping through Loch Assynt to the sea. Many prehistoric bones were stranded in the caves and found later. To encourage regeneration of trees (felled for quick profit or damaged by fire) two{exclosures}keep out animals.
